newsitem.title: USA: Politicians train guns on Iraq, not each other.
newsitem.headline: Politicians train guns on Iraq, not each other.

text.p: The U.S. attack on Iraq shifted the focus of the campaign on Tuesday, as President Bill Clinton used his power as commander-in-chief and opponent Bob Dole gave his patriotic support to the president's policy.
The two rivals ignored each other and instead denounced Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.
The Iraq situation enabled Clinton, who avoided military service in Vietnam, to appear as a bold and decisive commander. Wounded Second World War veteran Dole was left to support the president.

The United States launched the missile attack on Iraq in retaliation for Saddam's armed intervention in the Kurdish enclave of northern Iraq. Clinton also said he was expanding a no-fly zone over southern Iraq.

The White House played down the political aspects of the Iraqi situation and even injected a confident note of being "above the fray" by revealing that Clinton had telephoned Dole to personally advise him of the missile attack.
But the election is only nine weeks away and no actions by Clinton can be seen in a political vacuum.

The missile attack underscored Clinton's role as commander-in-chief, enabling him to somberly address the nation from the Oval Office, a setting with historical power and resonance that rival Dole cannot hope to match.

"Our objectives are limited but clear: to make Saddam pay a price for the latest act of brutality, reducing his ability to threaten his neighbours and America's interests," Clinton said from behind his Oval Office desk.
Dole backed away from his weekend criticism that Clinton had shown "weak" leadership against Saddam.
But while addressing an American Legion meeting in Salt Lake City, Dole muted the critique of Clinton's foreign policy and instead offered non-partisan, patriotic support.

"In matters like this, all of us think not as Republicans or Democrats, but as Americans. As Americans, we wish our troops success and safety," said Dole, who called Saddam "an outlaw," "a tyrant" and "a butcher."
His only jab at Clinton was a subtle one:

"If there is one clear lesson of our century it is this: When aggression is tolerated it multiplies," Dole said. "I trust this is the beginning of decisive action to limit the power and arrogance of Saddam Hussein."
In the short run, the Iraqi situation seemed likely to benefit Clinton, who is already well ahead in the polls.

The most recent survey, a USA Today/CNN/Gallup poll taken over the weekend and released on Tuesday, showed that Dole's boost from last month's Republican convention had evaporated. He was again trailing Clinton by 21 percentage points.
But if the Gulf crisis does not subside, it could spell trouble for Clinton.

"Crises in the short run work to the president's advantage," said Stephen Wayne, a government professor at Georgetown University in Washington. "Unresolved crises in the long run work to his disadvantage."
